Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the meeting invite flashing insistently. My team was gathering in five minutes to discuss critical project updates—details that wouldn’t be shared again. As a colleague, I was expected to be present, to contribute, to show I was part of the team. But just as I reached for my headset, the radio crackled with urgency. A major route closure had just been announced, and now dozens of flights were circling, waiting for instructions. As an air traffic controller, I was responsible for keeping those planes safe, for managing the sudden congestion in the sky. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford mistakes.” My heart pounded as I weighed the demands—my team counting on my input, pilots counting on my guidance. I felt the pressure building, torn between the meeting I couldn’t miss and the airspace I couldn’t abandon, caught in the impossible space between two worlds that needed me at the same time.
